ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The neutron total cross section of iron (natFe) plays an important role in the basic science of nuclear physics, nuclear technology and nuclear energy application. A new measurement of the total cross section of iron from 0.3 eV to 150 MeV was carried out in single and double bunch modes by transmission method and time of flight method with multi-cell fast fission ionization chamber (FIC) with 235U and 238U coating materials at the China Spallation Neutron Source (CSNS). Normalized fission counts-neutron energy spectra for sample-in and sample-out states were obtained and superimposed. The Bayesian method was used to eliminate the influence of the double-bunch problem on neutron measurement in the energy region above 10 keV. The transmissions obtained in single bunch and unfolded in double bunch coincided well. From 0.3 eV to 150 MeV, the ratio of most energy points of cross section in single bunch and in double bunch fluctuates within 10 %. In the energy range of 0.3 eV to 10 keV, the experimental results using 20 mm and 40 mm thickness iron samples both agree very well with the evaluated data of JEFF-3.3 and ENDF/B-VIII.0 at most energy points, fluctuating within 3 %. In the energy range of 10 keV to 150 MeV, the results agree well with the evaluated data in terms of values and trends. The main resonance peaks of the total cross section of iron at the energies of 3.94 keV, 6.24 keV, 7.76 keV, 27.9 keV, 52.1 keV, 74.1 keV, 83.9 keV, 141 keV, 170 keV, 188 keV and 386 keV are well represented in our results. The relative uncertainties of the total cross sections using the 40 mm iron sample by FIC-235U are within 2 % at most energy points. In 1.5 MeV-140 MeV region, the relative uncertainties of the total cross section using the 20 mm iron and 40 mm iron samples by FIC-238U are around 2 % and 1 %, respectively. The total cross section results can be used as a reference for nuclear data evaluation.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: The neutron total cross section represents the sum of the reaction probabilities between neutron and nucleons, which has a role of boundary condition in determining other reaction cross sections for a high resolution of a few percent and plays an important role in the basic science of nuclear physics, nuclear technology and nuclear energy application [1–3]. Iron (natFe) has a high atomic number and mechanical strength, which is widely used in the form of steel in the structural materials and shielding materials of nuclear devices [1]. The accuracy of the neutron total cross section of iron determines the reliability, economy and safety of iron-containing nuclear devices. Iron has been included in the list of the six isotopes for the Collaborative International Evaluated Library organization (CIELO) pilot project [4].

Yet the experimental and evaluated database of neutron total cross sections of iron have significant uncertainties and significant gaps in some regions [2]. The results of five recent experiments on natFe using white neutron sources were included in EXFOR [5]. Roland Beyer [1] et al. measured the iron total cross section from 150 keV to 8 MeV using scintillation detector at nELBE neutron time-of-flight facility in 2018 with the systematic uncertainty of 3 %−19 %. W. P. Abfalterer [2] et al. measured the iron total cross section in the 5.29–556 MeV range using scintillator at LANSCE facility at WNR in 2001 with statistical uncertainty of 0.6 %−1.5 %. W. P. Abfalterer [3] et al. also measured the iron total cross section in the energy range of 0.75–3 MeV using NE213 scintillator and 9Be(p, n) and 9Be(d, n) neutron sources at Ohio University in 2000 with statistical uncertainty of 0.6 %−11 %. K. Berthold [6] et al. measured the iron total cross section at the energy range of 0.75–2.2 MeV using scintillation detector at LINAC Linear accelerator in 1995 with the uncertainty of 0.6 %−7 %. J. A. Harvey [7] et al. measured the iron total cross section from 6.4 eV to 2.3 MeV using 6Li glass detector at ORELA in 1984 with uncertainty of 2 % to over 100 %. There are still significant differences between these experimental results in the overlapping energy regions. New measurements of the neutron induced total cross section of iron in a wider energy region are still need for clarification.

CSNS [8], which was built in early 2018, generates neutrons by impinging 1.6 GeV protons onto a thick tungsten target at a repetition rate of 25 Hz. Back-n white neutron source has been exploited to measure a variety of neutron cross sections with a high resolution. In this work, a new measurement of the total cross section on natFe samples had been carried out at the Back-n white neutron source of CSNS with double bunch mode and single bunch mode. The Neutron Total Cross Section Spectrometer (NTOX) facility was used based on a multi-cell FIC detector with high-purity 235U and 238U samples.

The measurement of neutron transmission with Time of Flight (TOF) method was performed. The neutron total cross section σ(Ei) can be calculated with Eq. (1):(1)σ(Ei)=−1nllnT(Ei)where nl is the number of atoms per unit area of the sample; T(Ei) is the experimental transmission which can be obtained with Eq. (2):(2)T(Ei)=CI(Ei)−BI(Ei)CO(Ei)−BO(Ei)×POPIwhere CI(Ei) and CO(Ei) are the neutron counts for the sample-in and the sample-out measurements at neutron energy Ei, which can be obtained by analyzing the signal waveform of the fast fission ionization chamber; BI(Ei) and BO(Ei) are the background counts for the sample-in and the sample-out measurements, which can be eliminated by background experiment and data analysis; PI and PO are the proton counts given by the accelerator monitor (Fast Current Transformer (FCT)) for the sample-in and the sample-out measurements.

The neutron energy Ei was measured with the TOF method using Eq. (3):(3)En=mnc2(11−(Lc×Tof)2−1)where mn is the mass of neutron; c is the speed of light; L is the length of neutron flight; Tof was the time of neutron flight which determined by Eq. (4):(4)Tof=Tf−(Tγ−Lc)where Tf is the time that neutrons were recorded in the form of fission fragments by the FIC; Tγ is the time recorded by FIC for the γ -flash produced at the same time as the neutrons; Lc is the time duration for gamma flash flight.

The present experiment was performed at the Back-n beam line of CSNS. The illustration of the experimental setup is shown in Fig.1 [8]. The iron samples were fixed on the automatic sample changer and placed at ES#1 about 55 m away from the spallation target. The FIC detector was placed at ES#2 about 21 m away from the iron samples.

This measurement was performed in the normal double bunch mode and single bunch mode with a pulse repetition rate of 25 Hz at the Back-n beam line of CSNS for higher count rates and higher energy resolution, respectively. The normal double-bunch mode means in each pulse there were two bunches of neutrons with a time interval of 410 ns and the single bunch mode means there were one bunch of neutrons in a cycle. The double bunches beam power was about 100 kW and the single bunch beam power was about 50 kW. The corresponding proton Gauss-type bunches had a length of about 60 ns (FWHM). The sizes of the neutron beam spots were 60 mm at ES#1 and 30 mm at ES#2, respectively.

In order to reduce statistical error and the influence of in-scattering, through a Monte Carlo simulation code [9], we selected 70 mm diameter samples of natFe with the iron purity of 99.95 % and the thickness of about 20 and 40 mm, respectively. The diameter, thickness and mass of the samples were measured by the vernier caliper or spiral micrometer and electronic balances respectively for several times. Atomic surface density is calculated by Eq. (5):(5)ρS=nl=4NmπMD2where N is the Avogadro's number, D is the diameter, M is the molar mass, m is the mass. The physical parameters and uncertainties of the iron samples are shown in Table 1. The discrepancy in atomic mass density uncertainties between the 20 mm and 40 mm specimens arises from differences in the measurement range and precision (0.1 g vs. 0.01 g) of the weighing balances employed.

The FIC detector was used to measure the fission counts-neutron energy spectra of the sample-in and sample-out states. The schematic structure and the physical picture of the FIC detector are shown in Figs. 2(a) and 2(b). The FIC detector had 8 fission cells consisting of four 235U cells, three 238U cells, and one uncoated cell. The direction of the neutron beam was shown by the black arrow in Fig. 2(a). FIC1 to FIC8 were installed from bottom to top, as shown in Fig. 2(b).

The FIC number and corresponding coating materials are shown in Table 2. The FIC [9] was filled with P10 (90 % Ar + 10 % CF4) gas at 0.8 atm pressure. The anode of each cell was an aluminum sheet with a radius (R) of 40 mm and a thickness of 0.09 mm. The cathode was a sheet of the same size with a sensitive zone diameter of 50 mm of fission material. The distance between the two electrodes was 5 mm and the voltage between the two electrodes was +200 V. This design ensures that fission fragments and secondary charged particles are stopped in the working gas. The MSI-8 preamplifier was used and connected to the data acquisition system (DAQ) via T signal. The DAQ [10] includes a Signal Conditioning Module (SCM), a Field Digitizing Module (FDM), a trigger & Clock Module (TCM) and a data center for storing waveform data. A cadmium filter was placed at the front of the neutron beam to cut off the neutrons with energies below 0.3 eV [11], and the width of the time window for DAQ acquisition was 0.01 s.

Two experiments were performed using single and double neutron beams, respectively. The first experiment was carried out with sample-out and 20 mm iron sample-in with single bunch mode for higher resolution of total cross section. The corresponding experimental durations were about 8 h and 12 h, respectively. For higher neutron counts, the sample-out, 20 mm and 40 mm Iron sample-in states were measured with double bunch mode for about 29 h, 41 h and 64 h, respectively. The experimental data of FIC cells were about 2 TB and they were analyzed through the ROOT software package developed by CERN based on C++ [12].

The signal waveforms of the 235U FIC-1 cell in double bunch mode and in single bunch mode through the T output port of the MSI-8 preamplifier obtained by the DAQ are shown in Fig. 3. The number of γ-flash signal waveforms in single and double bunch modes is 1 and 2, respectively. Moreover, the time interval of the two γ-flash signals in the two-bunch mode is 410 ns, which is exactly consistent with the interval of the two-bunch proton beam that produces the neutrons. Other FIC cell's signal waveforms are similar. Theγ-flash signals and the fission signals can be distinguished by comparing the amplitude and time information of the signals.

Tf in Eq. (4) is the time that neutrons were recorded and it was determined by the constant fraction timing method [13]. Tγ was determined by taking 1000 waveform superposition and constant fraction timing method, because Tγ is greatly affected by signal noise. The values of Tγ were −1117 ns and −1120 ns respectively in single and double bunch modes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Signal amplitude distribution and fission threshold setting
ce:section.ce:para: The signal amplitude distributions of FIC-1 and FIC-8 cells were analyzed by ROOT software package and they are shown in Fig. 4. The FIC-8 cell has no coating material. The difference of signal amplitude distribution between FIC-1 and FIC-8 was mainly caused by neutron-induced fissile material fission reaction. The signal amplitude distributions of other 235U and 238U cells were similar to that of FIC-1 cell.

As shown in Fig. 4(a), the dashed blue line represents the setting of fission amplitude threshold. Only the signal whose amplitude is greater than the fission threshold was considered for data processing. Because the magnification time of each channel of the MSI-8 preamplifier in this experiment was different, the fission thresholds were different, as shown in Table 3.

As described above, the neutron travels a distance of about 76 meters. It cannot be directly measured, but it can be obtained from the Tf−Tγ distribution of the FIC cells of 235U. As shown in Fig. 5, the Tf−Tγ distribution of the FIC cells of 235U has three characteristic peaks. According to the 235U fission cross section from the ENDF/B-VIII.0 [13], the corresponding neutron energies (Eres) of the three peaks are 8.78 eV, 12.38 eV and 19.29 eV, respectively. According to Eq. (3), the flight distance of FIC cells of 235U can be obtained. The flight distance of FIC-1, FIC-2, FIC-3 and FIC-7 were 77.147 m, 77.165 m, 77.184 m and 77.260 m, respectively. The nominal separation between adjacent FIC cells was designed as 18 mm. However, the derived inter-cell distances from calibration (≈19 mm) exhibit slight deviations due to the fitting uncertainties of Tf−Tγ and resonance energy (Eres). A 5 mm cumulative discrepancy across the array corresponds to a negligible 0.014 % uncertainty in the reconstructed energy of 1 MeV neutrons traversing the 77 m flight path. Specifically, the calibrated flight distances for FIC-4, FIC-5, and FIC-6 are 77.203 m, 77.222 m, and 77.241 m, respectively, consistent with the systematic error tolerance of the experimental setup.

The background of neutron total cross section experiment can be classified as time-dependent and time-independent background [14]. The time-dependent background is mainly scattered neutrons, which are produced by neutron beams interacting with shielding or structural materials and samples. X. Y. Liu [14] and Q. Li [15] had previously verified that this background has a negligible effect on the measurement at Back-n through absorption plate experiments combined with Monte Carlo simulations. The time-independent background mainly includes the environmental neutron and the spontaneous decay background caused by the fission material in the FIC. Q. Li [15] had measured the environmental background through the Bonner sphere spectrometer, and the results showed that the environmental neutron background of Back-n met the standard of nuclear data measurement. The background contributions arising from fission materials in the FIC and the γ-flash of neutron source can be effectively corrected by applying amplitude threshold discrimination and temporal window gating, respectively. Due to the significantly weaker γ-ray background and the fact that γ-rays interact with 235U and 238U predominantly within the energy range around 10 MeV, the contribution of laboratory γ-ray background to the total counting rate is negligible, amounting to less than one-millionth (<10−6) of the neutron-induced signal. By implementing multi-channel parallel processing and employing high-speed electronic components, the dead time and pile-up effects were significantly mitigated. Under the experimental conditions of a 1 GHz sampling rate and a counting rate of 103 cps, the dead time-induced counting loss was suppressed to below 10−5 [16,17].

This measurement was partly performed using the double bunch mode with a time interval of 410 ns. Due to the superposition of the event distributions of the double bunch mode, the resolution of the TOF measurement will be deteriorated and must be unfolded, especially in the high neutron energy region (>10 keV). A program package DemoUnfolding v3.4 that was based on the Bayesian unfolding method and developed and validated by H. Yi [18] was used in this work. After double bunch-unfolding, the energy spectra of the double bunches are the same as the theoretical energy spectrum of a single bunch. The Bayesian unfolding iterative algorithm can be written as Eq. (6):(6)Ci(k+1)=EiCi(k)Ci−Δ(k)+Ci(k)+Ei+ΔCi(k)Ci(k)+Ci+Δ(k)where Ei is the experimental counts of the ith TOF bin in double bunch mode, Ci is the calculated counts of the ith TOF bin under the corresponding single bunch, the superscript k means the kth iteration, Δ is the number of bins corresponding to the offset of 410 ns (Δ= 410 ns/w, w is the bin width of 40 ns). Fig. 6(a) shows the double bunch TOF spectrum in the TOF range of 200–55,600 ns measured by the representative FIC-1 in sample-out state and the unfolded TOF spectrum after double bunch unfolding.

After the unfolding iterations, the covariances of the bin counts in the unfolded distribution can be evaluated with the same Eq. (7) as in Ref. [16,18]. Fig. 6(b) shows the total absolute errors in every TOF bin after double bunch unfolding.(7)Cov[Ci(k),Cj(k)]=∑m,n∂Ci(k)∂Em∂Cj(k)∂EnCov[Em,En]

The Chi-square value and the Likelihood maximization value were considered to be the criterion of stopping the iteration [18], which change with the Iteration number as shown in Figs. 6(c) and 6(d). According to the Chi Square Calculator [19], the k is equal to 5 in this work.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Normalized fission counts-neutron energy spectra in single and double bunch modes
ce:section.ce:para: After determining the flight path distance and the time of flight, the fission counts-neutron energy distributions of the 235U and 238U FIC cells in single bunch mode can be obtained as shown in Fig. 7 with the neutron energy divided into 200 bins per decade (bpd). The counts-neutron energy distributions of the three FIC cells of the 238U coating materials are almost the same because the coating thicknesses of the 238U were similar. The coating thicknesses of the four FIC cell of the 235U coating materials were different, so the counts-neutron energy distributions were different. However, the working conditions were the same for multi-FIC cells. Therefore, in the subsequent analysis, we combined the counts of the four FIC cells of 235U into FIC-235U and the counts of the three FIC cells of 238U into FIC-238U.

According to Eq. (2), the fission counts spectra measured under different conditions should be normalized by the number of the protons. The number of the protons was positively correlated with the total number of neutrons under different conditions, which was obtained by proton monitor in the Rapid Cycling Synchrotron (RCS) and counting superposition.

The normalized fission counts-neutron energy spectra and the statistical errors of the fission counts of FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the single bunch mode are shown as Fig. 8. The bin width is also divided by logEn with 200 bpd. At most of the energy points, the counts can reach >1000, and the statistical errors are about 3 %. The distribution of the secondary chance fission can be distinguished obviously in the fission counts-neutron energy spectra of Figs. 7(a), 7(b), 8(a) and 8(b) in 6–8 MeV before and after superposition, which demonstrated not only the validity of the measurement but also the correctness of the superposition.

The normalized fission counts-neutron energy spectra and the total errors of fission counts of FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the double bunch mode had been also divided by 200 pbd and they are shown in Fig.9. The fission counts-neutron energy spectra between 0.3 eV and 10 keV do not need a double-bunch unfolding [18]. The fission counts-neutron energy spectra of FIC-235U were unfolded in the 10 keV to 150 MeV energy region to eliminate the influence of the two-bunch mode on the neutron energy resolution [18]. As shown in Fig. 9(c), at around 10 keV, the total errors of fission counts became about 3 times larger due to the double bunch unfolding.

In Figs. 8(a) 8(b) 9(a) and 9(b), the small fission counts at 0.3 eV-0.5 eV and above 140 MeV energy ranges appeared, caused by the relatively low neutron flux in these energy regions. In Figs. 8(b) and 9(b), the small fission counts at 1 MeV-1.5 MeV caused by the relatively low fission cross section of 238U. In Figs. 8(a) and 9(a), the fluctuations of fission counts in 0.5 eV to 5 keV are caused by the resonance cross section of 235U. The fluctuations of fission counts of 20 mm and 40 mm Iron-in states in 5 keV to 1 MeV are caused by the resonance cross section of iron. In the other energy regions, the total errors of fission counts were roughly within 1 %.

Through the normalized fission counts-neutron energy spectra obtained in Sect. 4.6, the transmission of iron with FIC-235U and FIC-238U can be obtained by Eq. (2) as shown in Fig.10. The transmission of 40 mm Iron-in was only measured with FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the double bunch mode. As can be seen from Fig.10(a), the calculated transmission of FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the 1–150 MeV energy region agree well. The transmissions of 20 mm Iron-in were measured with FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the double bunch mode and single bunch mode. As can be seen from Fig.10(b), at 0.3 eV to 10 keV, the transmissions of the 20 mm iron calculated at both double and single bunch modes agree very well. The limited experimental time in the single bunch mode resulted in the insufficient fission counts, so the fluctuations were larger than it in the double bunch mode. At 10 keV to 1 MeV, since there are many resonance peaks in the total cross section of iron, the transmissions calculated in the single and double bunch modes coincide well in Fig.10(b), which shown that the double bunch unfolding method is reliable. At 1–150 MeV, the measured transmissions of FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the single and double bunch modes were no significant deviation. However, the transmission results from the single bunch mode fluctuated greatly.

The measured neutron total cross section of iron with FIC-235U and FIC-238U in the single and double bunch modes can be obtained by Eq. (1) after the transmission obtained in Sect. 5.1. The total cross sections measured using 20 mm iron sample with FIC-235U in the single and double bunch modes are shown in Fig. 11. From 0.3 eV to 150 MeV, the ratio of most energy points of cross section in the single bunch and in the double bunch fluctuates within 10 %. The results of the total cross sections with the single and double bunch modes are consistent. However, the results of single bunch fluctuated greatly. So, the measurement results with the double bunch mode are recommended in preference.

Subsequently, the total cross section of natFe of this work and the previous experimental results [1–3,5,6] were compared with the evaluated data of JEFF-3.3 [20] and ENDF/B-VIII.0 [13] as shown in Fig. 12. The quantitative comparison of relative deviations ((X−ENDF/B-VIII.0)/ENDF/B-VIII.0, where X means the experimental results) versus neutron energy is shown in Fig. 13. The Mean Relative Percentage Deviations (MRPD ( %)) of experimental data vs ENDF/B-VIII.0 in defined energy bins are shown in Table 4. In the energy range of 0.3 eV-100 eV and 100eV-10 keV, the Mean Relative Percentage Deviations (MRPD ( %)) of our experimental results using 20 mm iron sample with ENDF/B-VIII.0 are 2.9 % and 6.0 %, which is obviously better than the degree 10.2 % and 21.9 % of J. A. Harvey. The fluctuation of our results in the range of 3.5 eV-9 eV was caused by the resonance cross section of 235U. The resonance peak of the total cross section of iron at 1.15 keV was not evident in our results, which was caused by the insufficient energy resolution of the detection system. The resonance peaks of the total cross section of iron in the energies of 3.94 keV, 6.24 keV and 7.76 keV were well represented in our results. In the energy range of 10 keV-1 MeV and 1–1000 MeV, the MRPDs of K. Berthod's experimental results are 9 % and 4 %; however, these results are confined to a narrow energy range of 0.75–1.57 MeV. Although the MRPDs obtained with a 40 mm iron sample using 235U are not optimal (60.1 % and 18.5 %), our results cover a broad energy range from 10 keV to 150 MeV. The resonance peaks of the total cross section of iron in the energies of 27.9 keV, 52.1 keV, 74.1 keV, 83.9 keV, 141 keV, 170 keV, 188 keV and 386 keV are well represented in our results.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Relative uncertainties of neutron energy and total cross section
ce:section.ce:para: The relative uncertainty of neutron energy (ΔEE) of Back-n facility is expressed [21] as Eq. (8):(8)ΔEE=11−(Lc×Tof)2×(11−(Lc×Tof)2+1)×(ΔTT)2+(ΔLL)2

ΔT and ΔL [21] are the total time error and the error of effective flight path, respectively.ΔT is about 60.3 ns, The value of ΔT is approximately 60.3 ns, mainly consisting of a half-width of the proton beam pulse of 60 ns and a time resolution of the detection system of 5.7 ns. The value of ΔL results from the moderation in the spallation target and the surrounding coolant, and can be determined by means of FLUKA simulation. According to Eq. (8), the relative energy uncertainty at some representative energy points of the FIC detector used in this experiment at approximately 77.2 m can be obtained, which are shown in Table 5.

The relative uncertainty of total cross section is mainly affected by the measurement uncertainty of the atomic surface density of natFe samples and the transmission relative uncertainty according to Eq. (1). According to Eq. (2), the transmission relative uncertainty is affected by the unfolded counting errors, background and proton flux detection results. Based on the analysis in Section 4.4, the background contribution is approximately 10−5. Since the monitoring system for the proton beam and the detection system for neutrons are entirely independent (with zero correlation), these variables can be considered statistically uncorrelated. Consequently, the relative uncertainty of the transmission [22] can be expressed in the form of Eq. (9).(9)ΔTT=(ΔCICI−BI)2+(ΔCOCO−BO)2+(ΔBICI−BI)2+(ΔBOCO−BO)2+(ΔPIPI)2+(ΔPOPO)2

Where ΔCI and ΔCO are the errors of fission signal's total count after double-bunch unfolding for the sample-in and the sample-out, ΔBI and ΔBO represent the errors of the total background count, ΔPI and ΔPO are the errors of the total proton (which generates neutrons) count for the sample-in and the sample-out, respectively.

The proton monitor FCT demonstrates a flux measurement precision within ±2 % for individual pulses [18]. In this study, the number of measured pulses exceeds 107, and the relative deviation in proton counts is rendered entirely negligible through statistical averaging. In this case, the dominant contributors to the relative uncertainty of the transmission are the relative uncertainty of unfolded counting with background corrected under both sample-in and sample-out conditions.

The uncertainty of atomic surface density (nl) is very small compared to the relative uncertainty of transmission and is therefore neglected. The relative uncertainty of total cross section for each energy bin can be calculated by Eq. (9) and is shown in Fig. 13.(10)Δσtot(Ei)σtot(Ei)=ΔT(Ei)nlσtot(Ei)T(Ei)

As shown in Fig. 14(a), in the energy ranges of 0.3 eV-10 keV and 300 keV-150 MeV, the relative uncertainties of total cross section are within 5 %. In the energy ranges of 0.3 eV-0.5 eV and above 140 MeV the relative uncertainties are higher because of the relatively low neutron flux in these energy regions. From 0.5 eV to 5 keV, the large relative error and fluctuation of the total cross section at some energy points are caused by the resonance cross section of 235U. In the energy range of 10 keV-300 keV, the relative uncertainties of total cross section at some energy points are very large for the resonance cross section of Iron. The relative uncertainties of total cross sections measured using the 40 mm iron sample with FIC-235U are within 2 % at most energy points.

As shown in Fig. 14(b), in the energy ranges of 1 MeV-1.5 MeV and 140 MeV-150 MeV, the large relative uncertainties of the total cross sections were caused by the relatively low fission cross section of 238U and the relatively low neutron flux. In 1.5 MeV-140 MeV, the relative uncertainties of the total cross sections measured using the 20 mm Iron sample and the 40 mm Iron sample with FIC-238U are around 2 % and 1 %, respectively.

A new measurement of the total cross section of iron (natFe) from 0.3 eV to 150 MeV was carried out by transmission method and time of flight method with FIC cells of 235U and 238U in single and double bunch modes at CSNS-Back-n. Two iron samples 99.95 % in purity with the thickness of 20 and 40 mm were used. Normalized fission counts-neutron energy spectra for sample-in and sample-out states were obtained and superimposed according to the fission counts of the 235U or 238U FIC cells. The transmissions measured in single bunch and the transmission after double bunch unfolding by the DemoUnfoldingv3.4 [18] based on the Bayesian unfolding method in double bunch mode coincided well. From 0.3 eV to 150 MeV, the ratios of the cross sections at most energy points from single bunch and from double bunch modes fluctuates within 10 %. However, the results from the single bunch mode fluctuated greatly and the measurement results from the double bunch mode were recommended. In the energy range of 0.3 eV-100 eV and 100eV-10 keV, the Mean Relative Percentage Deviations (MRPD ( %)) of our experimental results using 20 mm iron sample with ENDF/B-VIII.0 are 2.9 % and 6.0 %, which is obviously better than the degree 10.2 % and 21.9 % of J. A. Harvey. In the energy range of 10 keV-1 MeV and 1–1000 MeV, although the MRPDs obtained with a 40 mm iron sample using 235U are not optimal (60.1 % and 18.5 %), our results cover a broad energy range from 10 keV to 150 MeV. The resonance peaks of the total cross section of iron at the energies of 3.94, 6.24, 7.76, 27.9, 52.1, 74.1, 83.9, 141, 170, 188 and 386 keV are well represented in our results. The relative uncertainties of the total cross sections measured using the 40 mm iron sample with FIC-235U are within 2 % at most energy points. In the 1.5 MeV-140 MeV region, the relative errors of the total cross section using the 20 mm iron sample and the 40 mm iron sample with FIC-238U are around 2 % and 1 %, respectively. The larger uncertainties at a few energy points are due to the large total cross sections of iron, the small fission cross sections of the 235U or the 238U, or the relatively low neutron fluxes. The total cross section results of this work can be used as a reference for nuclear data evaluation. In the near future, we will analyze the resonance parameters of iron using the R-matrix method.
